hits.title: Assistant Professor in Aesthetics with focus on Critical Race/Decolonial Theory and Film
hits.job_description:
What are you going to do

You will provide education in a dynamic context with ample opportunities for the development of innovative teaching methods. Your research will be part of the Amsterdam School for Cultural Analysis (ASCA), one of the five research schools of the Amsterdam Institute for Humanities Research. ASCA is home to more than 100 researchers and more than 140 PhD candidates, and conducts world-leading research in Cultural Analysis. ASCA members share a commitment to studying culture in all its forms and expressions within an interdisciplinary framework, and to maintaining a close connection with contemporary cultural and political debates. All ASCA research fits into at least one, but usually more than one of five thematic constellations: 1) Mediality; 2) Arts & Aesthetics; 3) Globalization & Migration; 4) Identities; and 5) Cultural & Social Critique. Across these constellations, ASCA is seeking to build expertise on Global South cultures and critical race and decolonial theory.

The position will be embedded within the department of Philosophy in the capacity group ‘Critical Cultural Theory’ (CCT). This capacity group investigates art, cultural production/analysis, and aesthetics as forms of critique, specific experiences of modernity and “ways of worldmaking.” The position will be shared with the Media Studies department of the Faculty of Humanities, which offers both depth and diversity in its approaches to the study of media, with a wide range of academic offerings and research interests. It is the largest department of Media Studies in the Netherlands and is consistently highly ranked in international rankings. Our fields of expertise include Film studies, Cross-media culture, New Media and Digital Culture, Information studies, Digital humanities, Journalism, Archival Studies, Globalisation Studies, and Digital Heritage.

Tasks and responsibilities:

  • designing and conducting independent research on aesthetics, critical race/decolonial theory and, ideally, film-philosophy, resulting in academic publications in peer-reviewed international journals and/or books;
  • actively pursuing external funding for research, notably funding from research councils, national as well as European;
  • actively contributing to and developing national and international research networks and other forms of cooperation;
  • actively contributing to the interdisciplinary research activities of ASCA;
  • developing, coordinating and teaching courses in both Dutch and English, in the Bachelor and Master programmes;
  • supervising Bachelor and Master theses and tutoring students; co-supervising PhD theses;
  • actively contributing to the development and improvement of the broader teaching programmes in the department;
  • taking part in committees and working groups, and carrying out departmental administrative tasks as directed.

hits.title: PhD student on: "Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) in Interstitial Lung Disease: the M-ILD study"
hits.job_description:
Interstitial Lung Disease (ILD) prevalence is high and progressively increasing. Every year 500 new ILD-patients are diagnosed at Erasmus MC. Overall median ILD survival is poor ranging from 5 to 14 years. A recent landmark study demonstrated a reduction in ILD disease progression using costly anti-fibrotic drugs. However, half ILD-patients do not benefit from these expensive anti-fibrotic drugs, but could be better treated with anti-inflammatory or combined treatment. Hence, there is an unmet need for a monitoring tool to phenotype ILD-patients by assessing the amount of pulmonary fibrosis and inflammation to guide treatment choices and monitor response.

Current monitoring, namely computed tomography and lung function tests cannot differentiate between fibrotic lung disease and active inflammation. Chest Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) can offer a one-stop-shop solution for ILD providing structural and functional information in a single examination, such as ventilation inflammation perfusion and structure (VIPS-MRI).

The aim of this clinical project is to develop an innovative MRI technology for effective phenotyping, patient-tailored treatment guiding and monitoring of therapy response in ILD-patients through the quantification of both fibrosis and inflammation. A novel imaging chest-MRI protocol will be developed and compared to positron emission tomography MRI (PET-MRI) to quantify inflammation and fibrosis. Dedicated post-processing tools for advanced imaging analysis of chest-MRI will be developed. The PhD student will design the new MRI protocol and execute studies on patients with ILD. The PhD will also develop the needed advanced post-processing tools to quantify fibrosis and inflammation on MR images.

This clinical PhD project is embedded within theme Treatment in workpackage (WP) 6 of the national SYMPHONY research consortium. The SYMPHONY consortium is an interdisciplinary collaboration between many disciplines and patients (www.symphonyconsortium.nl). This consortium aims to orchestrate personalized treatment for patients with bleeding disorders in children and adults by establishing best treatment choice for each individual with a bleeding disorder based on bleeding tendency. This will be achieved by intensive collaborations between 12 workpackages (14 fte PhD and 1 fte postdoc).

In WP6, entitled: "Dose individualization of factor concentrates and desmopressin using population pharmacokinetic and pharmacodynamic modelling", six clinical and clinical pharmacology PhD students work closely together in the OPTI-CLOT/ To WiN study group. As clinical PhD (1 fte; only MDs, 3-4 years), you are responsible for the collection of data and patient samples from the six Hemophilia Treatment Centers in the Netherlands to develop and validate dosing models for expensive factors concentrates, desmopressin and other medication in unique prospective multicenter trials to treat bleeding disorders such as: hemophilia, von Willebrand disease. The ultimate goal of OPTI-CLOT is to optimize and implement personalized treatment, taking individual pharmacokinetics, lifestyle and bleeding phenotype into account, thereby improving quality of care. Background information about PK-guided dosing is found in this article published by the OPTI-CLOT study group: https://doi.org/10.1016/j.blre.2018.01.001

The clinical PhD student and clinical pharmacology PhD student, work jointly within defined projects. The clinical PhD student specifically: A) coordinates clinical studies; B) contacts patients in the clinic, outpatient department and/or during home visits; C) plays a pivotal role in connecting patients, medical doctors and nurses with clinical pharmacologists; D) collects and analyzes retrospective and prospective data of completed, current and new studies.

hits.title: Postdoc on the project: high frame rate echography of the heart
hits.job_description:
The current research line of high frame rate echography contains several projects, bringing high frame rate echography to the limit and beyond. We can slow down all fast cardiac motion and thus compile the full picture on the complex and adaptive cardiac beating, which encompasses blood flow, muscular motion, and blood perfusion. The postdoc is to further develop the techniques and bring them towards a preclinical (animal) study, to volunteers, and/or to pilot studies with patients. We have several technical implementations of the high frame technique, including a fully-programmable research scanner and high-end clinical scanners programmed to the needs of these projects.

Pre-clinical study
We will use 2D and 3D contrast-enhanced high frame rate imaging in a pre-clinical study to compare myocardial perfusion to gold-standard angiography around the left ventricle after induced ischemia (30 mins of occlusion vs. 2 h of occlusion, where no-reflow is expected for the second group but not the first). Pre-clinical experiments will be performed in close collaboration with the department of Experimental Cardiology.

Clinical study
In a pilot study (order of 45 subjects) we will use the perfusion measurements on volunteers and patients. We have a functioning framework for these 2D and 3D high frame rate techniques, including testing on performance.

For all tasks described above, the postdoc will be organising these experiments and overviewing the execution, and analysing the results in terms of both technical and physiological implication and relevance. Furthermore, the postdoc will contribute to the overall aims of the projects including national and international conference presentations, MSc and PhD supervision, and project reporting.

The work is part of the NWO-VIDI "QUANTO" project granted by the Dutch national research funding agency. These efforts aim at developing the technique from idea to bedside within 5 years, and will run both at the Erasmus MC University Medical Center Rotterdam and Delft University of Technology. The team consists of multi-disciplinary partners including PhD students, engineers and cardiologists and is supported by industry.

The research project should result in several peer-reviewed scientific publications.

hits.title: PhD student on genetic factors for obesity
hits.job_description:
Obesity is a global health care problem and forms a major risk factor for metabolic comorbidities such as diabetes, cardiovascular disease, and cancer. While the obesogenic environment has contributed to increased obesity rates, genetic factors modulate the susceptibility for obesity. Our research within the Obesity Center CGG (Centrum Gezond Gewicht) shows that obese patients frequently harbor genetic mutations or variants as an underlying cause of their obesity. Studies show that common polymorphisms in genes implicated in severe obesity modulate body mass index (BMI) and the risk for obesity in the general population.

In this project we aim to analyze the association of variants of genes involved in the leptin-melanocortin system and novel identified obesity-related pathways with BMI and obesity-related health issues (such as type 2 diabetes, cardiovascular disease) using population-based cohorts and translate results to our clinical obesity cohort.

hits.title: Postdoc on the project: high frame rate echography of the heart
hits.job_description:
The current research line of high frame rate echography contains several projects, bringing high frame rate echography to the limit and beyond. We can slow down all fast cardiac motion and thus compile the full picture on the complex and adaptive cardiac beating, which encompasses blood flow, muscular motion, and blood perfusion. The postdoc is to further develop the techniques and bring them towards a preclinical (animal) study, to volunteers, and/or to pilot studies with patients. We have several technical implementations of the high frame technique, including a fully-programmable research scanner and high-end clinical scanners programmed to the needs of these projects.

Pre-clinical study
We will use 2D and 3D contrast-enhanced high frame rate imaging in a pre-clinical study to compare myocardial perfusion to gold-standard angiography around the left ventricle after induced ischemia (30 mins of occlusion vs. 2 h of occlusion, where no-reflow is expected for the second group but not the first). Pre-clinical experiments will be performed in close collaboration with the department of Experimental Cardiology.

Clinical study
In a pilot study (order of 45 subjects) we will use the perfusion measurements on volunteers and patients. We have a functioning framework for these 2D and 3D high frame rate techniques, including testing on performance.

For all tasks described above, the postdoc will be organising these experiments and overviewing the execution, and analysing the results in terms of both technical and physiological implication and relevance. Furthermore, the postdoc will contribute to the overall aims of the projects including national and international conference presentations, MSc and PhD supervision, and project reporting.

The work is part of the NWO-VIDI "QUANTO" project granted by the Dutch national research funding agency. These efforts aim at developing the technique from idea to bedside within 5 years, and will run both at the Erasmus MC University Medical Center Rotterdam and Delft University of Technology. The team consists of multi-disciplinary partners including PhD students, engineers and cardiologists and is supported by industry.

The research project should result in several peer-reviewed scientific publications.

hits.title: PhD Candidate for Software Correctness
hits.job_description:
Software has shaped almost every aspect of our modern lives. Ensuring that software is correct, is both a major scientific challenge and an enterprise with enormous social relevance. Would you like to examine possibilities to introduce a theory for correctness levels for software? Then you have a part to play as a PhD Candidate.

The correctness of software is of major importance in computer science. Unfortunately, the significance of software correctness is not always clear. Furthermore, the automatic checking of software correctness is difficult. This leads to problems during system development projects and during the grading of software exercises. 

This PhD candidate position is intended for four years. You understand the importance of correct software and know how to work with several meanings of software correctness. Your goal is to introduce a generic and formal theory of software correctness levels, in which partially correct/incorrect software can be handled in a flexible way.

You will put the generic theory into practice, by experimenting with automatic grading of software exercises in the context of our courses. One application will be dealing with automatic grading of SQL statements. You will be supervised by Dr Patrick van Bommel and Prof. Djoerd Hiemstra.

hits.title: PhD Student – Senior Friendly Care Trajectories (1,0 fte)
hits.job_description:
We are recruiting a PhD candidate for a project on senior friendly care trajectories. You will will combine the scientific disciplines of Health Service Operations Management (HSOM) and Integrated Care to perform research on senior friendly care trajectories. With the aging of the population the number of patients with multi-morbidity is increasing. Older persons are living longer at home and frequently require a combination of cure, (home) care and social support. Episodes of hospital care, planned admissions or emergency situations, may entail changes in the care after discharge. Transfers between institutions and the home setting, as well as integration of care at home require planning and coordination to ensure continuity and quality of care for the patient. Delivering the right care on the right place at the right time ensures senior friendly and cost effective care with reablement as main aim. Reablement is “a person-centred, holistic approach that aims to enhance an individual's physical and/or other functioning, to increase or maintain their independence in meaningful activities of daily living at their place of residence and to reduce their need for long-term services”[1].  This may not only require optimizing the existing care organization, but also improving the care provision by developing innovative ways for care delivery and for transfers between institutional and home care.

Health Service Operations Management (HSOM) traditionally focusses on high production levels and efficiency, but shifted towards a more process-oriented approach with attention for the patient. However, until now, operations management research has mostly focused on institutional care, especially hospital care, and has paid less attention to care in the community and care in networks, while the number of days people stay in an institution is decreasing. This implies that applying OM approaches to primary care and to the home environment of patients create opportunities to enrich the knowledge base and transfer knowledge to new settings. An approach that focusses on the connection between primary and secondary care, and the alignment of care at home, whilst taking the network of the patient into consideration, is Integrated Care. Integrated Care research both focusses on patient populations, such as older persons, as on a specific disease, e.g. Diabetes or COPD. The expectation is that combining concepts and approaches of operations management and Integrated care will lead to possibilities to improve care for older persons living at home or nursing homes and add to delivering the right care on the right place at the right timeand reablement.

The research will be conducted in the province of Zeeland in close collaboration with healthcare organizations and professionals in that region. The PhD is expected to translate real life problems in the care trajectories in Zeeland into research that will benefit reablement and the optimization of care for older persons. As such the PhD will be member of the Academic Collaborative Centre Older Persons Care Zeeland (AWOZ), a collaborative network of health and research institutions. Information on AWOZ can be found on the following website: https://www.awoz.nl/

Finally, you will teach in the education programs of Erasmus School of Health Policy & Management (about 15% of your time).

[1] Metzelthin, S., Rostgaard, T., Parsons, M., & Burton, E. (2020). Development of an internationally accepted definition of reablement: A Delphi study. <i>Ageing and Society,</i> 1-16. doi:10.1017/S0144686X20000999

hits.job_description:
As a clinical study manager at MRIguidance, a UMC Utrecht spin-off company, you will be responsible for the regulatory strategy and the setup, management and follow up of clinical studies, which are of utmost importance for the validation and certification of our product portfolio to facilitate market entry.

What you tell at birthdays about your job

“The company I work for prevents cancer in patients that need to undergo a bone scan. Nowadays, if someone needs a bone scan, radiologists use an x-ray based CT scan which exposes the patient to harmful radiation. The BoneMRI technique we developed is a radiation-free alternative that provides both bone and soft tissue information using only one machine and one exam. This reduces patients' burden, and saves time and money for hospitals. My job is to make sure our products are tested on patients in hospitals around the world and that our methods are safe and effective.”

What you actually will be doing

At MRIguidance, the performance of clinical validation studies is a crucial part towards CE and FDA certification and clinical introduction of our medical products. Your task will be the planning, management and administration of these clinical research and validation studies. Utilising existing templates and standard operating procedures in line with ISO 14155 and the MDR as a guide, you will help in setting up, implementing and monitoring these studies. With your proactive attitude you will familiarise yourself with applicable guidelines, regulations and requirements for these studies. You will facilitate communication and interaction with participating medical centers, medical ethical and legal organisations in Europe and the USA. An important part of your work is ensuring the study is properly documented. You keep track of the planning and timelines. You will be part of the clinical team and will be supported by the current clinical study managers and the QA officer of MRIguidance and report to the Head of clinical affairs.

Your responsibilities:

  • Project management;
  • Study administration;
  • Design, write and review ethics approvals and regulatory submissions;
  • Design, write and review study documents (clinical investigation plans and reports);
  • Maintain contact with doctors and researchers from participating medical centers, both in the
  • Netherlands and abroad;
  • Monitor and stimulate patient inclusion.

hits.title: Wetenschappelijk onderzoeker
hits.job_description:
Wij zijn op zoek naar een gedreven en enthousiaste wetenschappelijk onderzoeker voor 32-36 uur per week met expertise in analyseren van longitudinale datasets en interesse in praktijkrelevant en/of epidemiologisch onderzoek.

Wat houdt de functie in?
Voor ongeveer de helft van je aanstelling doe je werkzaamheden voor DREAMS (www.dreams-study.nl). DREAMS is een landelijk samenwerkingsverband tussen de vier grote, academische instellingen voor kinder- en jeugdpsychiatrie. Dit zijn Accare, LUMC Curium (Leiden), Karakter (Nijmegen) en Levvel (Amsterdam). Het doel van DREAMS is om de kinder- en jeugdpsychiatrische zorg en beloop van psychopathologie in Nederland beter in kaart te brengen en zo de zorg te verbeteren, bijvoorbeeld door voorspellers van behandelsucces te onderzoeken. Ook wordt er gekeken naar de impact van actuele maatschappelijke thema’s, zoals de huidige Covid-19 crisis, op de kinderen en jeugdigen die bij de deelnemende instellingen in zorg zijn. Het DREAMS samenwerkingsverband is een nieuw wetenschappelijk consortium en biedt veel mogelijkheden om eigen interesses in de mentale zorg voor kinderen en jongeren om te zetten in concrete onderzoeksprojecten.

De andere helft van je aanstelling werk je met bestaande datasets met een focus op het schrijven van wetenschappelijke artikelen. Zo zijn er data beschikbaar van een onderzoek binnen Accare dat zich richt op de relatie tussen contextuele variabelen en succes van behandeling. Bovendien zijn er klinische en genetische gegevens beschikbaar van grote longitudinale cohorten zoals ALSPAC, EMTICS en TIC Genetics. De laatste twee hebben betrekking op kinderen met ticstoornissen. Een speerpunt van het onderzoek bij Accare is daarnaast het verminderen van onnodig medicatiegebruik bij kinderen en jongeren met ADHD of gedragsproblemen. Je helpt ons dit onderzoek verder vorm te geven en een brug te slaan met de klinische praktijk. Het betreft een veelzijdige en uitdagende functie met als doel het onderzoeksteam van het Child Study Center blijvend te versterken en het longitudinale onderzoek verder uit te bouwen.    

Je voornaamste taken en verantwoordelijkheden zijn:

  • Je hebt een leidende rol en bent (samen met het team van wetenschappelijk onderzoekers) verantwoordelijk voor de inhoudelijke, organisatorische en logistieke aspecten van de onderzoeksprojecten;
  • Je bent een verbindende factor tussen de afdeling onderzoek en de klinische praktijk;
  • Je zorgt voor implementatie van processen ten behoeve van dataverzameling van gegevens uit de klinische praktijk;   
  • Je schrijft onderzoeksvoorstellen en neemt initiatief in het vormgeven van het onderzoek bij onze onderzoeksafdeling, met nadruk op klinisch relevante vraagstukken;
  • Je rapporteert de onderzoeksbevindingen in publicaties in (inter)nationale vaktijdschriften;  
  • Je verspreidt vergaarde kennis binnen Nederland en op internationale congressen.

hits.title: PhD Scholarship Innovative Business Models in Agriculture (1.0 FTE)
hits.job_description:
Scholarship opportunity
Campus Fryslân invites applications for a four-year PhD scholarship candidate to complete a dissertation on the topic of innovative business models in agriculture. Within Campus Fryslân, you will be joining the Sustainable Entrepreneurship in a Circular Economy department in which senior scholars and PhD researchers develop a wide variety of research lines and projects including leadership, business models, innovation, and societal impact (http://www.rug.nl/cf/cse).

Agriculture is important for the Northern region of the Netherlands. However, the financial forecasts of farmers is challenging and the social appreciation of current business models has declined. The efficiency farming business models is at the end stage of its life cycle among others because of the large-scale negative ecological effects. As a result, niche farmers in the region innovate and develop new business models based on the opportunities and limitations of nature. These new business models have systemic implications for value chain partners, government policies and consumer behaviour. The new business models directly contribute to the triple bottom-line performance of farmers and their context.

The PhD research enables farmers to identify farm-specific quick wins and systemic new ecological and social added value (including water quality, nitrogen and biodiversity). The farmers will learn how to capture these new added value propositions derived from their stand-alone firms or in collaboration with regional co-stakeholders and colleague farmers. The PhD research will analyse the success factors of the design, implementation, management and regional dissemination of new farming business models.
Broad topics of interest of the doctoral research include (but are not limited to):

• What are the barriers and the success factors of innovative business models?
• What is the added value of innovative business models for farmers and the region?
• How can new value chains for innovative business models successfully be developed and implemented?
• How can regions develop ecosystems for innovative business models?

You will benefit from the large business networks with regional and national innovative farmers and existing programs on new business models (https://uvhn.maglr.com/inspiratieboek/universiteit-van-het-noorden). You will be enrolled in the Graduate School of Campus Fryslân. You will be co-supervised by Prof. Gjalt de Jong (promotor) and Dr Niels Faber (co-promotor).

The PhD candidate will be enrolled in the Graduate School Campus Fryslân (GSCF). If interested, the PhD candidate could also have a role to play in the Master program Sustainable Entrepreneurship.

hits.title: PhD position Roman sarcophagi in Lebanon (1.0 FTE)
hits.job_description:
Applications are invited for a fully funded, four-year PhD position within the research project “Mortuary Archaeology of the Roman East - MARE”, financed by the Dutch Research Council (NWO) and led by the PI, dr. Lidewijde de Jong.

During the first centuries CE, new forms of funerary display emerged in the cemeteries of the Roman Near East. Memories of the deceased were prolonged after death through portraits and epitaphs, monumental stone coffins, and roadside tombs. This project investigates how these forms of displaying the dead were embedded in mortuary rituals. Bringing legacy dataset anddigital archives together, we interrogate how local communities reformulated their relationships with the dead by personalizing the funerary spaces.

In collaboration with the other team members, you will work on your own project Encoffined Bodies: decorated sarcophagi in funerary customs in Coastal Lebanon. Burial in stone coffins, many decorated in relief, was a popular practice in the Near East under Roman rule. Being part of a funerary context, the coffins played a role in the proper care for and remembrance of the deceased. As a container for the corpse - simultaneously protecting the body and hiding its disintegration- it speaks directly to concepts of the body held by the burying community, and to the role of the materiality of the coffin and its decoration in the care for the dead. This PhD project investigates the ritual function of sarcophagi in their material, epigraphic, and pictorial setting. The research concentrates on the coast of Lebanon, which had a long history of use of coffin burials. Legacy collections from older excavations and epigraphic or art historical surveys form the core dataset. Contextual data comes from recent rescue excavations, such as those in Beirut.

An outline of the complete project is available at: https://www.rug.nl/research/groningen-institute-of-archaeology/research/mare/

This PhD project offers a unique opportunity to work in an international research environment as well as to acquire valuable teaching experience: the PhD candidate is expected to conduct 0.3 fte teaching during the second, third and fourth year of their appointment (0.1 fte yearly).

You will be asked to:

• complete a dissertation on the ritual function of sarcophagi in Roman Lebanon
• collect legacy and new data together with the principal investigator and other team members
• assist other team members in developing the visual/iconographic components of the project’s digital database
• co-organize research meetings and an online exhibit
• contribute to the project’s public outreach and social media activities
• participate in GIA, ARCHON, and other related events
• conduct a limited amount of teaching.

hits.job_description:
Applications are invited for a fully funded, four-year PhD position within the research project “Mortuary Archaeology of the Roman East - MARE”, financed by the Dutch Research Council (NWO) and led by the PI, Dr Lidewijde de Jong.

During the first centuries CE, new forms of funerary display emerged in the cemeteries of the Roman Near East. Memories of the deceased were prolonged after death through portraits and epitaphs, monumental stone coffins, and roadside tombs. This project investigates how these forms of displaying the dead were embedded in mortuary rituals. Bringing legacy dataset anddigital archives together, we interrogate how local communities reformulated their relationships with the dead by personalizing the funerary spaces.

In collaboration with the other team members, you will work on your own project Rituals in Space: reconstructing funerary rituals through gifts and bones. This PhD project focuses on the activities that occurred in the space of the tomb, from the first burial and post-burial actions, to its closure or abandonment. Through the analysis of the spatial setting, grave gifts, and human remains, the different steps in funerary rituals are reconstructed. This will give insights into the shared beliefs that the communities drew on in the care for the dead. This research builds a framework in which the fragmented materials of the Roman Near East can be inserted. It addresses the project’s main question by outlining how people interacted with the dead through ritual actions, and the extent to which the new tomb elements altered these practices. The sample comes from Coastal Lebanon and Pisidia (Turkey) and consist of legacy and new data on the spatial setting of human remains, coffins, epitaphs, and gravegoods.

An outline of the complete project is available at: https://www.rug.nl/research/groningen-institute-of-archaeology/research/mare/

Health Technology Research and Innovation Cluster; We are HTRIC

Health Technology and Innovation Cluster (HTRIC) is een gezamenlijk initiatief van de Rijksuniversiteit Groningen en het UMCG, samen met onder andere De Hanzehogeschool, NHL Stenden en het Life Cooperative. HTRIC verbindt onderzoek, gezondheidstechnologie en klinische praktijk voor meer gezonde jaren.
Om onze ambitie “gezondheidstechnologie voor meer gezonde jaren” waar te maken zijn wij op zoek naar een energieke en verbindende onderwijscoördinator.
In de rol van onderwijscoördinator ben je verantwoordelijk om de ambitieuze doelstelling van HTRIC te vertalen naar concrete onderwijsprogramma’s. Centraal hierbij staat de methodiek design thinking die in alle programma’s de basis moet vormen. Je verbindt hierbij het interne netwerk van kennispartners onderling en aan dat van onze bedrijfspartners. Aan de kennisinhoudelijke collega’s voeg je organisatiekracht toe en voer je strakke regie als het om planning en rolverdeling gaat. Door jouw enthousiasme en inzet leveren netwerkpartners graag hun bijdrage.

hits.title: Postdoc 'Normative modelling of the human visual system'
hits.job_description:
We have a vacancy for an excellent post-doctoral research associate to work on a project focusing on the development and application of advanced methods for the analysis of the human visual system based on clinical neuroimaging data. The project is hosted by the Donders Institute for Brain, Cognition and Behavior at the Radboud University Medical Center (Cognitive Neuroscience department) under the supervision of Dr. Koen Haak and integrated into the wider academic research environment at the Donders Institute.

The focus of this project is to develop normative models of various functional and structural magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) measures of the human visual system based on existing large-scale neuroimaging datasets, and apply these (in collaboration with the department of ophthalmology) to better understand an individual's neural response to vision loss (e.g. neural plasticity, neural degeneration) and how this response might explain individual differences in functional vision in daily life activities. You will employ a range of MRI data-analysis techniques (structural and functional connectivity modeling, brain morphometry) including established and advanced approaches (e.g. connectivity gradient modeling, connective field modeling) and implement a software platform to enable other researchers and clinicians to take advantage of the innovations produced in this project.

Tasks and responsibilities
  • Discuss, plan and perform research in a stimulating environment.
  • Develop normative models of the human visual system using large-scale MRI datasets.

hits.title: PhD student on: "Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) in Interstitial Lung Disease: the M-ILD study"
hits.job_description:
Interstitial Lung Disease (ILD) prevalence is high and progressively increasing. Every year 500 new ILD-patients are diagnosed at Erasmus MC. Overall median ILD survival is poor ranging from 5 to 14 years. A recent landmark study demonstrated a reduction in ILD disease progression using costly anti-fibrotic drugs. However, half ILD-patients do not benefit from these expensive anti-fibrotic drugs, but could be better treated with anti-inflammatory or combined treatment. Hence, there is an unmet need for a monitoring tool to phenotype ILD-patients by assessing the amount of pulmonary fibrosis and inflammation to guide treatment choices and monitor response.

Current monitoring, namely computed tomography and lung function tests cannot differentiate between fibrotic lung disease and active inflammation. Chest Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) can offer a one-stop-shop solution for ILD providing structural and functional information in a single examination, such as ventilation inflammation perfusion and structure (VIPS-MRI).

The aim of this clinical project is to develop an innovative MRI technology for effective phenotyping, patient-tailored treatment guiding and monitoring of therapy response in ILD-patients through the quantification of both fibrosis and inflammation. A novel imaging chest-MRI protocol will be developed and compared to positron emission tomography MRI (PET-MRI) to quantify inflammation and fibrosis. Dedicated post-processing tools for advanced imaging analysis of chest-MRI will be developed. The PhD student will design the new MRI protocol and execute studies on patients with ILD. The PhD will also develop the needed advanced post-processing tools to quantify fibrosis and inflammation on MR images.

Inleiding:

Het lectoraat richt zich op de transitie in stroomgebieden van beken en rivieren naar natuurlijk en duurzaam functionerende systemen die kunnen inspelen op de effecten van wisselende en extreme klimaatomstandigheden (te veel, te weinig, te smerig). Focus is daarbij de ontwikkeling en engineering van ‘nature-based solutions’ vanuit morfologisch en hydrologisch perspectief. Hierbij is ook oog voor de internationale context, zowel ten aanzien van grensoverschrijdende stroomgebieden als van delta’s wereldwijd.

De extreme weerssituaties vragen om een maatschappelijke transitie waarbij invulling wordt gegeven aan de centrale en structurerende rol van het bodem- en watersysteem bij het versterken van ruimtelijke kwaliteit. Dit sluit aan op het advies van PBL ‘Grote opgaven in een beperkte ruimte’ (2021). Belangrijke vraagstukken in stroomgebieden zijn de aanpak van droogte en het voorkomen van wateroverlast. Een ander vraagstuk betreft de erosie van rivierbodems met de daaraan gerelateerde gevolgen voor onder meer waterveiligheid, zoetwatervoorziening, scheepvaart en natuur. In het Deltaprogramma is aangegeven dat het treffen van maatregelen nodig is om te voorkomen dat een deel van de Waal, het Pannerdensch kanaal en de IJssel over 50 jaar tot wel een meter dieper liggen dan nu het geval is. Wat zijn mogelijke oplossingen om dit aan te pakken? Wat zijn de effecten daarvan? Wat is de effectiviteit en haalbaarheid.

In het lectoraat wordt onderzocht welke interventies toepasbaar zijn in stroomgebieden om deze op meer natuurlijke wijze te laten functioneren. Daarbij kan het onderzoek zich bijvoorbeeld richten op sedimentatieprocessen en stromingspatronen en invloeden van factoren zoals vegetatie daarop. Bij het onderzoek hoort uiteraard ook het verzamelen, analyseren en adequaat beheren van data en informatie. Dit kan ook gaan over de bijdrage die de interventies kunnen leveren aan bredere maatschappelijke doelen zoals het versterken van biodiversiteit en de energietransitie. Op deze wijze kan vanuit het lectoraat verbinding worden gelegd met de Omgevingswet waarmee duurzame ontwikkeling en bescherming van de kwaliteit van de leefomgeving wordt beoogd.

 De functie omvat: 

  • het ontwikkelen van nieuwe kennis, producten, processen en diensten leidend tot beroepsinnovatie, curriculumvernieuwing, verder onderzoek, publicaties, presentaties en strategische positionering;
  • het leiding geven aan een te vormen kenniskring, het professionaliseren van beginnende docentonderzoekers en het begeleiden van docentonderzoekers, promovendi/postdocs;
  • het verrichten van praktijkgericht onderzoek binnen de kaders die gesteld zijn in de Gedragscode Wetenschappelijke Integriteit;
  • het leveren van een bijdrage aan de verbinding tussen onderwijs en onderzoek en actief bijdragen aan de inhoudelijke kwaliteit, de innovatie (curriculumvernieuwing) en de uitvoering van het onderwijs (bijvoorbeeld door het geven van colleges en het begeleiden van afstudeerders);
  • het acquireren van onderzoeksopdrachten;
  • het actief verspreiden van de uitkomsten en inzichten uit het lectoraatsonderzoek naar de beroepspraktijk en maatschappij;
  • het onderhouden en uitbreiden van een relevant intern en extern netwerk in onderwijs, onderzoek en beroepspraktijk;
  • het samenwerken over de grenzen van het eigen lectoraat met andere lectoren binnen en buiten Hogeschool Van Hall Larenstein;
  • het meewerken aan processen en systemen t.b.v. de borging en verhoging van onderzoek- en onderwijskwaliteit;
  • een spilfunctie binnen de driehoek onderzoek, onderwijs en (beroeps)praktijk.

The Leiden Institute of Physics (LION) offers a faculty position in experimental quantum matter and optics, with a research emphasis on electronic properties of matter. The successful candidate will have the freedom to develop an independent research program in this field, connecting to and expanding on existing research at LION. Our own research in this area focuses on (engineered) quantum materials, with quantum optics and photon-matter interactions as adjacent fields of interest, while reaching out to the interface between physics and chemistry. A new research group is starting up shortly, focusing on van der Waals materials.

Our new colleague will have full access to the joint infrastructure, which includes extensive thin film preparation, nanolithography (including EBPG and FIB), magnetotransport facilities below 1 K, and microscopy techniques such as low-temperature STM, LEEM, AFM, break junctions, and various single-molecule fluorescence techniques. hits.title: Postdoc - How do microalgae grow and move within porous hydrogel environments?
hits.job_description:
Engineered living materials are hybrid structures composed of biological living cells, which are growing within a non-living matrix. The living cells within the matrix can endow the materials with a range of novel sense-and-respond functionalities.

The aim of this project is to exploit the light response of microalgae to provide responsive properties to a microalgae-based living material. To achieve this, the postdoc will investigate how the microalgae C. reinhardtii grows and moves within a porous hydrogel environment and how it responds to light in the context of such a confined environment. The role of specific proteins involved in mechanosensing and in surface adhesion will be examined by visualizing C. reinhardtii motion with time-lapse microscopy. The insights that we will gain on mechanosensing within a porous structure will enable us to better control the algae’s response by, for example, adjusting conditions affecting mechanosensing proteins or using genetic variants with altered mechanosensation.

With the support of technicians and experts in the research team, the postdoc will identify the characteristics of the cell movement as a function of the environmental conditions, genetic variation, and materials’ parameters. This will enable the rational design of strategies to control the living material response.

The role

 As a project manager, it is your responsibility to bring our projects to a timely and successful end.

  • Acquisition:
    You play an important role in connecting to our ecosystem on the Brightlands Smart Services Campus in Heerlen. This includes the active acquisition of new projects and identifying & analyzing opportunities. You represent BISS in regular meetings to connect the different stakeholders. The acquisition is a shared responsibility between the project manager, BISS’ Principal Investigators (Professors from Maastricht University who are part of the BISS team), and BISS’ Managing Director. 
  • Project definition:
    You support the BISS Principal Investigators in formulating draft project definitions and deliverables. The PI’s act as Product Owners and are responsible for the content of the project definition, whereas you are responsible for making sure there are definitions and deliverables in place before the project commences, and that there is a realistic timeline in which milestones are defined.
  • Project management:
    The projects that you manage, are carefully planned, and progress is monitored. We currently use a SCRUM board, but you are explicitly welcome to make this role your own by implementing your preferred processes.
  • Leading the project:
    You select the right team members, based on expertise and availability. You motivate and coach the project members. You ensure that their roles are well-defined and that everyone’s responsibilities are clear. You are their first point of contact regarding the project. You lead the team members, as well as the meetings with different stakeholders. You have the authority to decide on how to prioritize tasks within the project definition and within budget. In case of larger desired changes of scope or budget, you decide together with the Managing Director (MD).
  • Project Reporting:
    Not only do you ensure that customers and partners receive an end-report and evaluate the project with us, you pro-actively identify additional ways to give the project external visibility. You actively use your lessons learned to make the next project better, smoother, or more successful. You monitor the project budget, together with MD and PI.
  • Developing the team:
    You are the project manager for our most strategic, or larger projects. At the same time, you develop the project management skills of the researchers and developers in the BISS team, so that they can do project management for smaller projects themselves. You implement joint processes and approaches and share best practices, to support the team. You advise them when needed, without taking over.

hits.title: PhD student for clinical SYMPHONY project
hits.job_description:
This clinical PhD project is embedded within theme Treatment in workpackage (WP) 6 of the national SYMPHONY research consortium. The SYMPHONY consortium is an interdisciplinary collaboration between many disciplines and patients (www.symphonyconsortium.nl). This consortium aims to orchestrate personalized treatment for patients with bleeding disorders in children and adults by establishing best treatment choice for each individual with a bleeding disorder based on bleeding tendency. This will be achieved by intensive collaborations between 12 workpackages (14 fte PhD and 1 fte postdoc).

In WP6, entitled: "Dose individualization of factor concentrates and desmopressin using population pharmacokinetic and pharmacodynamic modelling", six clinical and clinical pharmacology PhD students work closely together in the OPTI-CLOT/ To WiN study group. As clinical PhD (1 fte; only MDs, 3-4 years), you are responsible for the collection of data and patient samples from the six Hemophilia Treatment Centers in the Netherlands to develop and validate dosing models for expensive factors concentrates, desmopressin and other medication in unique prospective multicenter trials to treat bleeding disorders such as: hemophilia, von Willebrand disease. The ultimate goal of OPTI-CLOT is to optimize and implement personalized treatment, taking individual pharmacokinetics, lifestyle and bleeding phenotype into account, thereby improving quality of care. Background information about PK-guided dosing is found in this article published by the OPTI-CLOT study group: https://doi.org/10.1016/j.blre.2018.01.001

The clinical PhD student and clinical pharmacology PhD student, work jointly within defined projects. The clinical PhD student specifically: A) coordinates clinical studies; B) contacts patients in the clinic, outpatient department and/or during home visits; C) plays a pivotal role in connecting patients, medical doctors and nurses with clinical pharmacologists; D) collects and analyzes retrospective and prospective data of completed, current and new studies.

Om onze activiteiten op het gebied van evaluatie en impact assessment in Nederland en daarbuiten te versterken, zijn wij in Amsterdam op zoek naar een gemotiveerde evaluatie-expert met bewezen trackrecord. Wij zoeken een collega die aantoonbare ervaring heeft met zowel beleidsadvies, diverse evaluatie- en impact assessment methodieken, als met het managen van complexe projecten, bij voorkeur op Europees niveau. 

In deze functie identificeer en genereer je nieuwe business leads en schrijf je projectvoorstellen voor (voornamelijk) evaluatieprojecten op het snijvlak van wetenschaps-, innovatie- en technologiebeleid en maatschappelijke uitdagingen. Als projectleider ben je verantwoordelijk voor de goede uitvoering van projecten die kunnen variëren in omvang, duur en complexiteit. Je werkt graag in teamverband en bent in staat om samen te werken met, en ondersteuning te bieden aan, een projectteam van ervaren en beginnende consultants. Je overlegt met klanten en partners in binnen- en buitenland, waarvoor je bereid bent te reizen indien nodig.

Om (complexe) beleidsvraagstukken te kunnen beantwoorden, ben je in staat om een gedegen methodologische aanpak te ontwikkelen voor evaluaties en impact assessments van beleid, programma’s en (kennis)instituten. Je verricht analytisch werk, zowel zelfstandig als in teamverband. Verworven inzichten weet je treffend te vertalen in heldere rapportages, waarbij partijen uit het beleids- en onderzoeksdomein je voornaamste doelgroep zijn. Je werkt samen met collega’s in Amsterdam, maar ook regelmatig met collega’s in buitenlandse kantoren van Technopolis en met externe partners. hits.title: Teamleider Connectivity/Netwerk
hits.job_description:
Ben jij in staat met een team van netwerkspecialisten de transitie naar een nieuw netwerk te volbrengen? Zorg jij voor die positieve vibe in het team en een prettig werkklimaat zodat de medewerkers onder jouw hoede kunnen floreren in deze uitdagende omgeving? Dan zijn we op zoek naar jou!

Als teamleider van het team Connectivity stuur je een team van 12 fijne collega’s (netwerkspecialisten) aan, die graag op een laagdrempelige manier met elkaar werken. Voor deze functie zijn we op zoek naar iemand die op een natuurlijke wijze het team aanstuurt, op conceptueel niveau kan meedenken met de netwerkprofessionals, ideeën naar concrete plannen vertaalt, maar niet naar iemand die direct aan de knoppen zit.

Het team Connectivity beheert en ontwikkelt de complexe netwerkinfrastructuur van de Radboud Universiteit. Momenteel wordt de netwerkomgeving van de Radboud Universiteit vernieuwd, waarbij vele nieuwe technieken worden toegepast (o.a. Software Defined Networking). Het 'nieuwe' netwerk wordt gefaseerd opgebouwd op basis van Cisco apparatuur. Kennis van nieuwe (Cisco) technieken / implementaties is daarom een pré. Binnen het team hou jij het overzicht. Met jouw helicopterview ben je in staat om nieuwe implementaties te realiseren. Je bent op de hoogte van technische ontwikkelingen en vindt het ook leuk het team mee te nemen in deze ontwikkeling. Je hebt een sterk analytisch vermogen, proactieve houding en denkt ‘out of the box’. Je bent in staat snel te schakelen binnen de organisatie, zowel horizontaal als verticaal. Als teamleider ben je bekend met de terminologie van ITIL, Prince en/of Agile en kan je acteren in een procesgerichte organisatie.

Samenwerken op diverse niveaus en kennis delen zijn belangrijke succesfactoren voor de toekomst van de afdeling IT Service waar jij werkzaam zal zijn. We verwachten daarom dat deze kwaliteiten in jouw genen zitten. Op een fijne manier samen successen behalen, daar draait het om! hits.title: Postdoctoral Researcher in Virology
hits.job_description:
The project

The COVID-19 pandemic demonstrates how underprepared the world has been for emerging pandemic respiratory viruses, such as SARS-CoV-2. Although vaccines have been developed, SARS-CoV-2 is still actively spreading and new variants are constantly emerging. The impact of new mutations in the viral proteins responsible for viral replication and transcription is still poorly understood. We recently developed a SARS-CoV-2 mini-genome assay to identify new inhibitors of SARS-CoV-2 replication and test the effect of mutations in the viral replication proteins on viral RNA synthesis and the sensitivity of SARS-CoV-2 to current antivirals, such as remdesivir or favipiravir.

About your role

We are looking for an enthusiastic postdoc to work a joint project between the Laboratory of Applied Evolutionary Biology of the Amsterdam University Medical Center (location AMC), the National Institute for Public Health and the Environment (RIVM), and the Department of Molecular Biology of Princeton University. The appointed postdoc will work on a ZonMW/NWO funded project to study SARS-CoV-2 replication and the impact of mutations in variants of concern (VoC) on SARS-CoV-2 sensitivity to antivirals and replication kinetics.

The postdoc will be primarily responsible for the continued development of the SARS-CoV-2 replication activity assay, the screening of inhibitor libraries, and the testing of emerging SARS-CoV-2 mutations using in vitro and virus assays. There will be ample opportunities to develop other skills and contribute to multiple aspects of the project.

hits.title: Promovendus: neurocognitieve ontwikkeling van kinderen met sikkelcelziekte
hits.job_description:
Wat ga je onderzoeken?
Dagelijks worden wereldwijd 1.000 kinderen met sikkelcelziekte geboren. Sikkelcelziekte is een erfelijke bloedziekte, waarbij de rode bloedcellen makkelijk kunnen veranderen in een sikkelcelvorm. Deze sikkelcellen zorgen voor obstructie in kleine bloedvaten waardoor het zuurstofrijke bloed niet goed aankomt bij organen en weefsels. Dit kan leiden tot allerlei ernstige levenslange complicaties, waaronder schade aan het hersenweefsel. Deze schade kan ernstige gevolgen hebben voor de ontwikkeling en het functioneren van kinderen met sikkelcelziekte waardoor hun kwaliteit van leven, schoolprestaties en carrière vooruitzichten beperkt worden. Daar komt bij dat sikkelcelziekte vaker voorkomt binnen reeds maatschappelijk benadeelde families met een migratieachtergrond. Dit onderzoek heeft als doel om vroegtijdig kinderen met sikkelcelziekte met een bedreigde ontwikkeling te identificeren zodat vroege interventies mogelijk worden.

De promovendus zal onderzoek uitvoeren in twee projecten (ONSET en BRICK):

Objective Neurocognitive Assessment of Young Children with Sickle Cell Disease by Eye-Tracking (ONSET)
Vanwege de bedreigde neurocognitieve ontwikkeling van kinderen met sikkelcelziekte is het van groot belang om deze beperkingen vroeg op te sporen, zodat de zorg voor deze kinderen daarop kan worden afgestemd. ONSET richt zich op het in kaart brengen van de vroege neurocognitieve ontwikkeling van jonge kinderen met sikkelcelziekte. In het onderzoek wordt gebruik gemaakt van een versneld longitudinaal design met eye-tracking bij kinderen van 4 tot 24 maanden. Eye-tracking is een veelbelovende methode om objectieve metingen van neurocognitieve functies te verrichten bij babies en peuters. In deze studie wordt tevens de predictieve waarde onderzocht van klinische karakteristieken (waaronder proteomics) voor de neurocognitieve ontwikkeling.

Brain Structure and Neurocognitive Development in Sickle Cell Disease (BRICK)

Vanwege de verstrekkende impact van sikkelcelziekte op de neurocognitieve ontwikkeling van kinderen is het belangrijk om de mechanismen die leiden tot neurocognitieve beperkingen in detail te begrijpen. De BRICK studie maakt gebruik van biomarkers en geavanceerde beeldvorming met MRI om meer inzicht te verkrijgen de onderliggende mechanismen van de neurocognitieve beperkingen. Het onderzoek richt zich op kinderen en jongeren met sikkelcelziekte tussen de 6 en 24 jaar. Dit onderzoek wordt samen met het Sophia Kinderziekenhuis (Erasmus MC) uitgevoerd, waarbij het Emma Kinderziekenhuis verantwoordelijk is voor de neurocognitieve metingen.

Wat ga je doen?
De afdeling Kinderhematologie en de Emma Neuroscience Group van het Emma Kinderziekenhuis (Amsterdam UMC) werken samen aan innovatief onderzoek dat is gericht op de vroege neurocognitieve ontwikkeling van kinderen met sikkelcelziekte. Hierbij wordt gebruik gemaakt van biomedische methoden (proteomics) en neurowetenschappelijke methoden (eye-tracking en computergestuurd neurocognitief onderzoek). De promovendus zal onderzoek uitvoeren in twee projecten (ONSET en BRICK).

Taakomschrijving
De vacante positie omvat onder andere de volgende taken:

  • Rekruteren van kinderen met sikkelcelziekte in het Emma Kinderziekenhuis;
  • Rekruteren van een gezonde controlegroep (4-24 maanden) via het consultatiebureau;
  • Supervisie van dan wel het uitvoeren van neurowetenschappelijke metingen (eye-tracking, neurocognitief testonderzoek);
  • Superviseren van master-studenten in het uitvoeren van metingen en het schrijven van een master-these;
  • Management van de datastromen die voortvloeien uit het beschreven onderzoek (in Castor);
  • Data-analyse middels verschillende softwarepakketten (SPSS, R);
  • Het schrijven van een proefschrift op basis van de resultaten uit de beschreven projecten.

hits.title: Arts onderzoeker TURN-COVID
hits.job_description:
Wat ga je onderzoeken?

Nieuwe antivirale middelen kunnen een mogelijk keerpunt zijn in de preventie en behandeling van patiënten met COVID-19. TURN-COVID is een nationale cohortstudie gericht op het gebruik van neutraliserende monoklonale antilichamen en andere antivirale SARS-CoV-2 middelen als therapie tegen COVID-19. Doel van de studie is om het gebruik, effectiviteit, veiligheid en kosten van de verschillende middelen in kaart te brengen in een Nederlandse setting. Ook onderzoeken we de virale kinetiek, het mogelijke ontstaan van nieuwe SARS-CoV-2 mutanten tijdens therapie en de antistofrespons. Bovendien creëren we een landelijk platform om toekomstige nog niet geregistreerde behandelingen van COVID-19 te evalueren.

We verzamelen klinische gegevens en nemen vragenlijsten af bij patiënten die behandeld worden met monoklonale antilichamen en andere antivirale middelen tegen SARS-CoV-2. In een aantal centra verrichten we de biobank studie waarbij we neus-mond swabs en bloed verzamelen op verschillende tijdspunten om de virale kinetiek, het eventuele ontstaan van nieuwe virus varianten en de antistofrespons te onderzoeken.

Momenteel loopt de TURN-COVID studie in meer dan twintig Nederlandse ziekenhuizen. De TURN-COVID studie wordt geleid door hoofdonderzoekers Prof. Joost Wiersinga (internist-infectioloog) en Dr. Godelieve de Bree (internist-infectioloog) en projectleider Dr. Emma Birnie (postdoc en arts in opleiding tot internist). Je zal nauw samenwerken met verschillende promovendi, een onderzoeksverpleegkundige en medische studenten. Het initiatief is tot stand gekomen met steun van de SWAB, RIVM, Nederlandse Vereniging van Ziekenhuisapothekers, GGD, Stichting HIV monitoring, en verschillende wetenschappelijke- en patiëntenverenigingen en wordt gesubsidieerd door ZonMw. 

Wat ga je doen?

Als promovendus op dit project zal je verantwoordelijk zijn voor het uitvoeren van de TURN-COVID studie. De werkzaamheden zijn zeer afwisselend.

Concreet houd jij je hierbij voornamelijk bezig met:

  • Coördineren van een multi-center studie
  • Includeren van patiënten
  • Gegevens verzamelen in de deelnemende centra
  • Laboratorium analyses van verzamelde sampels
  • Data analyse middels verschillende softwarepakketten (bv R)
  • Beantwoorden en analyseren van welomschreven onderzoeksvragen
  • Presenteren van resultaten op (internationale) congressen
  • Schrijven van wetenschappelijke publicaties en een proefschrift
  • Superviseren van studenten

hits.title: Arts-onderzoeker Vaatchirurgie
hits.job_description:
Wat ga je onderzoeken?
Het betreft een langlopend project dat gefinancierd wordt door de AMC-foundation. De afgelopen jaren zijn meerdere collega’s binnen dit project gepromoveerd. Het doel van het project genaamd “het aneurysmaprogramma” is om op termijn de sterfte aan een aneurysma van de abdominale aorta te kunnen verminderen. Daarvoor is eerder o.a. gekeken naar biomarkers en innovatieve beeldvorming om een aneurysma beter in beeld te krijgen, we hebben gekeken naar prognostische factoren en naar man-vrouw verschillen. De bedoeling is om deze onderzoeken verder uit te breiden en te verbreden. Binnen het project is ook een studentonderzoeker aangesteld als datamanager om samen met de PhD student de biobanken uit te breiden.

De invulling van het onderzoek zal mede afhankelijk van de wensen en de capaciteiten van de aan te stellen PhD student worden vastgesteld.

Wat ga je doen?
Als PhD student bij de Vaatchirurgie ben je verantwoordelijk voor de coördinatie van de bestaande biobanken waarin gegevens en materialen van patiënten met een aneurysma van de aorta zijn opgeslagen. Je taak omvat het identificeren van kandidaten (patiënten) voor deelname aan de biobanken, het benaderen van de patiënten en het vragen om informed consent. Ook patiënten die in de biobank zijn opgenomen en die voor controle komen moeten op de polispreekuren worden herkend en benaderd voor het verzamelen van vervolggegevens.

Je hoofdtaak is het doen van onderzoek op het gebied van de patiënten met een aneurysma. Dit onderzoek kan gelieerd zijn aan de gegevens die in de biobanken verzameld zijn. Je krijgt ook een rol bij trials die wij nu opzetten en kan hier ook over publiceren. Deelname aan een internationale trial staat in de planning.

Wat ga je onderzoeken?

De afdeling Kinderhematologie van het AMC biedt een positie aan voor een enthousiaste arts-onderzoeker voor een onderzoeksproject op het gebied van hemofilie A. Sinds kort kunnen bloedingen bij patiënten met een ernstige vorm van hemofilie worden voorkomen met een innovatieve behandeling, emicizumab. De kennis over het gebruik van emicizumab in jonge kinderen is beperkt. Het doel van dit project is om te onderzoeken welke effecten emicizumab heeft op bloedingen, gewrichtsschade en de immunologische reactie op stollingsfactor VIII van jonge kinderen met hemofilie A. Er worden verschillende metingen verricht: de behandeling met emicizumab en stollingsfactor VIII, bloedingen, bijwerkingen en verschillende laboratorium tests. Het project zal in een multicenter verband worden uitgevoerd binnen Nederland en mogelijk ook andere Europese landen.

Wat ga je doen?

  • Coördineren van de multicenter studie

About the role
As Assistant professor you will harness various (big) omics data and combine this with the current understanding in immunology to better understand intestinal diseases. Specifically, we are looking for a faculty member whose background will allow them to successfully develop a dynamic and collaborative research program that focusses on intestinal diseases (IBD in particular) by making use of state-of-the-art bioinformatic tools to study aspects of the disease progression and treatment success. Accordingly, the faculty member should have a strong background in both immunology and bioinformatics and be willing to develop their own research line within the Tytgat Institute, where the candidate will be expected to establish and maintain a vigorous program of independent, externally funded research and to contribute to undergraduate and graduate teaching programs.

The functions of a member of the academic staff include, in varying proportions: a) research, b) teaching/scholarly activities, c) supervision of graduate students and other research trainees, e) applications to grants; the position comes with full salary but no bench fees; recruitment of external funds is expected in this role.

The Assistant Professor is expected to contribute to the management and performance of the Gastroenterology department through participation at relevant meetings and taking on selected responsibilities relevant to the role (e.g. efficiency programs, recruitment of staff, facilities etc.), and to be responsible for the leadership of project(s) and delivery on project objectives, maintain an up-to-date understanding of scientific developments within the appropriate fields, and ensure a high level of scientific standard is maintained on all programs.

About the workplace?
The Tytgat Institute of Liver and Intestinal Disease, at the Faculty of Medicine at the Amsterdam University Centers, invites applications for a tenure-track faculty position related to Bioinformatics/Immunology of Intestinal Disease within the Department of Gastroenterology and Hepatology. hits.title: Postdoc position on 'Data-model integration of (past) East Asian Monsoon climate dynamics’ (2 years, 1.0 FTE)
hits.job_description:
The Department of Earth Sciences currently seeks a highly-motivated and skilled applicant for a postdoctoral position to work on integrating multi-proxy records of past East Asian Monsoon climate with Earth system model outputs. This is a work package of the VIDI project 'Elucidating monsoon dynamics: deconvolving temperature and precipitation signals in East Asian Monsoon climate reconstructions’, awarded to Dr Francien Peterse, funded by the Netherlands Organization for Scientific Research (NWO).
The East Asian Monsoon (EAM) is one of the strongest monsoon systems on Earth, and will likely be affected by ongoing global warming. However, data-model comparison is complicated due to the mixed signals in paleoreconstructions. The current position aims to synthesize individual proxy records of temperature and precipitation for the EAM domain and to compare them with climate model simulations. These proxy records are being generated within the same project based on lipid biomarkers, their isotopic composition, and clumped isotope measurements on land snails from several sections of the Chinese Loess Plateau (CLP). The availability of precipitation isotope reconstructions will furthermore allow comparison with isotope enabled climate model outputs. The research will be performed at Utrecht University in The Netherlands.

The candidate should be fluent in spoken and written English, since the host group is highly international in composition.

hits.title: Postdoctoral fellow, Early-stage quantitative sustainability assessment of emerging technologies (0.8-1.0 fte)
hits.job_description:
The Faculty of Science and Institute of Environmental Sciences  are looking for:

Postdoctoral fellow, Early-stage quantitative sustainability assessment of emerging technologies (0.8-1.0 fte)

Vacancy number: 22-079

Key responsibilities  

We are looking for an outstanding postdoctoral fellow to support an ongoing European project. The project supports the research & innovation around new ideas towards radically new future technologies. The project has been focusing on the development of a new generation of protonic devices, which could radically change the technological landscape. The 21st century has seen an unprecedented proliferation of electronic devices, sharply altering the world economic map and human sociological behaviour. A biomimetic solution is being sought in the project by the development of organic electrochemical transistors and proton transistors using organic/biopolymers and composites. You will be supporting the ongoing early-stage sustainability assessment of this new generation of technologies using life cycle assessment (LCA), working hand-in-hand with top material and technology developers in Europe. The ideal starting date for the position is May 1st 2022.

Key tasks include:

  • Develop new methods to support early-stage quantitative sustainability assessment of emerging technologies;
  • Perform a quantitative sustainability assessment of the new technological setup using life cycle assessment (LCA);
  • Innovate on LCA methods to assess emerging technologies at low TRLs;
  • Support the technology developers in the project with the identification of the most promising design options from a sustainability perspective.
hits.requirements_description:

Selection Criteria

  • You should have a PhD in a relevant field, and ideally have proven already to be productive in terms of scientific output. Relevant backgrounds include, but are not limited to, PhDs in industrial ecology, quantitative sustainability science, innovation studies, engineering and modelling.
  • Knowledge of and experience with LCA is a strong advantage.
  • Data management, visualization and programming skills (e.g. in Matlab, Python or R) are an advantage.
  • Experience with the techno-economic assessment of emerging technologies is an advantage.
  • You must be proficient in spoken and written English, have good communication skills. Previous teaching experience will also be valued.
  • Moreover, you are a team player, are able as well to work independently, take initiative, and have a strong interest and motivation to pursue academic research.

hits.title: Postdoc researcher on theory and quantitative economic modelling for a circular economy
hits.job_description:
The postdoctoral researcher/teacher will work on the Horizon Europe project “CircoMod - Circular economy modelling for climate change mitigation”. Its aim is to model how circular economy (CE) strategies impact GHG emissions and resource efficiency. The researcher will contribute to the project by extending existing economic theories and models with circular economy features. Extensions include the representation of secondary markets and material balances, including a vintage structure in the resource use block, and linking material physical flows to trade patterns, sector value-added, primary and secondary material use, regional competitiveness, and resource (in)dependence. Through the project the researcher collaborates with a diverse group of European researchers on economics, climate, material flows, and policy making.

 

The new researcher will work with prof. Reyer Gerlagh on the economic modelling activities and with Dr Asel Doranova on policy dialogues and work with stakeholders. The project is expected to lead to publications in top field journals.

 

The job includes a 25% teaching task consisting of thesis supervision and teaching in Python-related programming courses and environmental economics courses.

hits.title: Assistant Professor Practical Philosophy in Medical Ethics and Politics of Health
hits.job_description:
The Philosophy and Public Affairs group covers a broad field of expertise in practical philosophy. The group seeks to strengthen its profile by hiring a candidate that (a) has a solid background in either political and social philosophy or ethics (b) the ability to connect socio-political themes with ethical perspectives c) a research focus on a contemporary, urgent and topical issue. In the last decade, fueled by bio-technological developments, issues of bioethics have become more and more pertinent, facing us with an ever more complex set of analytical and normative tasks. In addition, the corona-pandemic has once again shown the importance of questions of a just distribution of health care and the effects of health policies, our views on the value of human life, our images of wellbeing, illness and recovery, as well as intricate bioethical questions such as triage. Given these challenges, we are therefore looking for a colleague with a specialization in Medical Ethics and the Politics of Health. 

What are you going to do?

You will provide education in a dynamic context with ample opportunities for the development of innovative teaching methods. Your research will be part of the Amsterdam School for Cultural Analysis (ASCA), one of the five research schools of the Amsterdam Institute for Humanities Research. ASCA is home to more than 100 researchers and more than 140 PhD candidates, and conducts world-leading research in Cultural Analysis. ASCA members share a commitment to studying culture in all its forms and expressions within an interdisciplinary framework, and to maintaining a close connection with contemporary cultural and political debates. All ASCA research fits into at least one, but usually more than one of five thematic constellations: 1) Mediality; 2) Arts & Aesthetics; 3) Globalization & Migration; 4) Identities; and 5) Cultural & Social Critique. Across these constellations, ASCA is seeking to build expertise in the Medical Humanities.

The position will be embedded within the department of Philosophy in the capacity group Philosophy and Public Affairs (PPA). Philosophy and Public Affairs examines classical questions in the area of practical philosophy, such as the foundations of ethics and sociopolitical philosophy, in light of new and topical problems.

Tasks and responsibilities

  • Designing and conducting independent research on Medical Ethics and the Politics of Health resulting in academic publications in peer-reviewed international journals and/or books.
  • Actively pursuing external funding for research, notably funding from research councils, national as well as European.
  • Actively contributing to and developing national and international research networks and other forms of cooperation.
  • Actively contributing to the interdisciplinary research activities of ASCA.
  • Developing, coordinating and teaching courses in both Dutch and English, in the Bachelor and Master programmes.
  • Supervising Bachelor and Master theses and tutoring students; co-supervising PhD theses.
  • Actively contributing to the development and improvement of the broader teaching programmes in the department.
  • Taking part in committees and task forces and carrying out departmental administrative tasks as directed.
hits.requirements_description:
Requirements

What do you have to offer?

The ideal candidate has a strong training in practical philosophy, including the history of the field, as well as a specialization in Medical Ethics and Politics of Health, engaging with issues such as bioethics and biopolitics, health justice, disability, the ethics and politics of care, or clinical ethics. The ability to situate these questions within a broader framework and to combine them with related questions such as human rights, ecology, analyses of capitalism, gender relations or disability studies is especially welcome. We expect the candidate to be highly interested in interdisciplinary collaboration within ASCA and other research schools, combining philosophical inquiry with sociological, cultural, and political analysis. The role of philosophy will be relevant in enriching an interdisciplinary cooperation with a normative perspective. This UD position will play vital role, not only in attuning the PPA group to one of the most pressing crises of our times, but also in building up an infrastructure within ASCA for future research in the Medical Humanities.

Your experience and profile:

  • hold a PhD in Philosophy with a research focus on Medical Ethics and the Politics of Health;
  • hold an international academic network in the research area concerned;
  • provide research output commensurate with the level of the position;
  • active and ambitious researcher with a strong publication record;
  • demonstrable ability and ambition to obtain external research grants;
  • broad and relevant teaching experience at BA and MA level;
  • excellent command of both Dutch and English, If Dutch is not the mother tongue, an active and passive command must be acquired within two years of the employment contract and the state examination for Dutch as a Second Language programme II must be passed;
  • experience with digital and audiovisual teaching facilities and affinity with IT in university teaching;
  • experienced in valorisation and practice-based education and/or research;
  • good team player and versatile at all levels, capable of multidisciplinary co-operation;
  • excellent organisational experience and skills;
  • acquired the Dutch Basic Teaching Qualification, or is willing to acquire this within the first two years.

hits.title: PhD student on genetic factors for obesity
hits.job_description:
Obesity is a global health care problem and forms a major risk factor for metabolic comorbidities such as diabetes, cardiovascular disease, and cancer. While the obesogenic environment has contributed to increased obesity rates, genetic factors modulate the susceptibility for obesity. Our research within the Obesity Center CGG (Centrum Gezond Gewicht) shows that obese patients frequently harbor genetic mutations or variants as an underlying cause of their obesity. Studies show that common polymorphisms in genes implicated in severe obesity modulate body mass index (BMI) and the risk for obesity in the general population.

In this project we aim to analyze the association of variants of genes involved in the leptin-melanocortin system and novel identified obesity-related pathways with BMI and obesity-related health issues (such as type 2 diabetes, cardiovascular disease) using population-based cohorts and translate results to our clinical obesity cohort.

  • Experience in managing and analyzing genome-wide genotype data.
  • Basic understanding of the biology of obesity and metabolic disorders.
  • Experience in the programming languages R and/or python.
  • Experience of multi-trait genetic association analysis, polygenic risk scores, and/or Mendelian randomization is an advantage.
  • Excellent communication and writing skills in Dutch and/or (academic) English.

hits.title: Lector Ondermijning
hits.job_description:
U stelt een onderzoeksplan op, werft opdrachten, onderhoudt contacten met de beroepspraktijk en wetenschap en begeleidt docenten en studenten in hun ontwikkeling.

Mooi werk
U werkt voor een vernieuwd lectoraat van het oude Expertisecentrum Veiligheid (EV). U wilt binnen dit thema kennis ontwikkelen door het (laten) verrichten van praktijkgericht onderzoek, waarbij u ervoor zorgt dat de inhoudelijke en methodologische kwaliteit van het onderzoek goed is en de wisselwerking tussen onderzoek, onderwijs en werkveld optimaal. Dit doet u door kenniskringen met docent-onderzoekers in te richten en hen te coachen. Door studenten en professionals een leeromgeving aan te bieden. En door in- en extern op te treden als expert en kwaliteitsdrager van allerlei onderzoeksgerelateerde zaken. U werft extern gefinancierde projecten die passen in de context van het onderwijs en het onderzoeksthema.

De kern van het onderzoek van het lectoraat is het inzichtelijk maken hoe processen en mechanismen van ondermijning werken, welke rol burgers, professionals en hun organisaties daarbij spelen en hoe deze weerbaarder gemaakt kunnen worden tegen deze ontwikkelingen. Ondermijning wordt gedefinieerd als de ontwrichting van maatschappelijke structuren en fundamenten en aantasting van de rechtstaat, door verwevenheid van onderwereld en bovenwereld, als gevolg van of verbonden met georganiseerde criminaliteit. Ondermijnende criminaliteit is vooral een economisch gedreven maatschappelijk fenomeen.

Bij de aanpak van ondermijnende criminaliteit zijn veel partijen betrokken op verschillende niveaus. De insteek van de aanpak is al even divers en hangt samen met de variëteit aan partijen. Belangrijke spelers zijn de opsporingsdiensten en het openbaar ministerie, de belastingdienst en lokale overheden, maar ook professionals in het sociaal domein, de zorg en bijvoorbeeld woningcorporaties. Elk van de betrokken partijen heeft zijn eigen instrumentarium, gekoppeld aan bevoegdheden en expertise. De sleutel tot een effectieve aanpak ligt in samenwerking tussen partijen en de uitwisseling van informatie en expertise.

En hierin ligt dan ook de kern van de onderzoeksopgave van dit lectoraat:

  • Het vergroten van de weerbaarheid van professionals, dienstverleners en branches. Door zelf weerbaar te zijn tegen directe ondermijnende activiteiten, maar ook door het signaleren van ondermijnende activiteiten en hiertegen in actie te komen
  • Het vergroten van de weerbaarheid van burgers: welke factoren stimuleren en belemmeren de meldingsbereidheid aan de overheid en hoe zijn deze te beïnvloeden.
  • Het versterken van de samenwerking tussen betrokken organisaties voor het creëren van meer impact dan alleen voldoen aan de eisen van ieders eigen organisatie: hoe om te gaan met de effectiviteit van het instrumentarium van elke partner t.o.v. elkaar? Hoe te komen tot ‘ons’ instrumentarium? Wat vereist dat van de professionals en de organisaties van de toekomst?

In de eerste termijn van het lectoraat zijn drie onderzoekslijnen ontwikkeld, samen met de beroepspraktijk en het onderwijs: Indicatoren ten behoeve van vroegsignalering van ondermijning met gebruik van data, Weerbaarheid van het openbaar bestuur en Burgerparticipatie.

Voor de komende lectoraatsperiode is met de stakeholders nagegaan waar de grootste kennisbehoefte uit bestaat: de huidige thema’s zijn nog steeds actueel. Daarnaast blijkt er behoefte aan een meer systeemgerichte benadering van het thema ondermijning, is er ruimte voor de bestudering van fysieke aspecten van ondermijning en is verdergaande aansluiting bij de nationale en internationale beleidsagenda’s gewenst, waarbij de huidige en nieuw op te zetten onderzoekslijnen worden geïntegreerd.
